items.title: Judge orders release of 5-year-old Liam Ramos, his father from detention
items.standfirst: A federal judge ordered the release of 5-year-old Liam Ramos and his father from Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention in Texas. The boy was detained last week while on his way home from preschool, sparking an international outcry. Ian Lee has more.
items.content: A federal judge ordered the release of 5-year-old Liam Ramos and his father from Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention in Texas. The boy was detained last week while on his way home from preschool, sparking an international outcry. Ian Lee has more.

items.title: Judge orders 5-year-old boy and his dad released from ICE detention, citing ‘incompetently-implemented government pursuit of daily deportation quotas’
items.standfirst: A 5-year-old boy and his father must be released by Tuesday from the Texas center where they’ve been held after being detained by immigration officers in Minnesota, a federal judge ordered Saturday in a ruling that harshly criticized the Trump administration’s approach to enforcement. items.title: Judge orders release of 5-year-old Liam Ramos and his dad from ICE detention
items.standfirst: A judge has ordered the U.S. to release a father and 5-year-old son who were taken into custody during the immigration crackdown in Minnesota. A judge previously ruled that they could not be removed from the U.S. for now.

clusters.title: Israeli air strikes kill at least 32 Palestinians in Gaza, rescue officials say
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli air strikes kill at least 32 Palestinians in Gaza, rescue officials say

items.title: Israeli air strikes kill at least 32 Palestinians in Gaza, rescue officials say
items.standfirst: Israel's military confirmed the strikes, which come during a ceasefire that Israel and Hamas accuse each other of breaking.
items.content: Israel's military confirmed the strikes, which come during a ceasefire that Israel and Hamas accuse each other of breaking.

items.title: Israeli strikes kill 30 Palestinians, including children, as Gaza ceasefire inches forward
'There's no ceasefire': Israeli strikes kill 30 Palestinians, including children, in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israeli air strikes killed at east 30 people in Gaza Saturday, including children, according to hospitals, as the military said it attacked in response to a Hamas ceasefire violation. Despite a US-brokered ceasefire entering its second phase earlier this month, violence in the Palestinian territory has continued, with both Israel and Hamas accusing each other of violating the truce agreement.
items.content: Israeli air strikes killed at east 30 people in Gaza Saturday, including children, according to hospitals, as the military said it attacked in response to a Hamas ceasefire violation. Despite a US-brokered ceasefire entering its second phase earlier this month, violence in the Palestinian territory has continued, with both Israel and Hamas accusing each other of violating the truce agreement.

items.title: Children and police officers among at least 30 killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza
items.standfirst: Deadly attacks launched day before border crossing due to open as part of ceasefire dealIsrael has carried out some of its deadliest airstrikes on Gaza in months, killing at least 30 Palestinians, some of whom were sheltering in tent cities for displaced people.Despite a nominal ceasefire, the Israeli military struck a police station in the Sheikh Radwan neighbourhood west of Gaza City on Saturday, killing 10 officers and detainees, the civil defence said. It indicated the death toll could rise as emergency responders searched for bodies. Continue reading...
items.content: Deadly attacks launched day before border crossing due to open as part of ceasefire dealIsrael has carried out some of its deadliest airstrikes on Gaza in months, killing at least 30 Palestinians, some of whom were sheltering in tent cities for displaced people.Despite a nominal ceasefire, the Israeli military struck a police station in the Sheikh Radwan neighbourhood west of Gaza City on Saturday, killing 10 officers and detainees, the civil defence said. It indicated the death toll could rise as emergency responders searched for bodies. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli strikes on Gaza kill dozens as violence continues despite ceasefire
items.standfirst: Hospitals in Gaza said Israeli strikes killed at least 29 Palestinians Saturday, one of the highest tolls since the October ceasefire aimed at stopping the fighting. A day after Israel accused Hamas of new ceasefire violations, strikes hit locations throughout Gaza, including lethal ones on an apartment building in Gaza City and a tent camp in Khan Younis, officials at hospitals that received the bodies said.
items.content: Hospitals in Gaza said Israeli strikes killed at least 29 Palestinians Saturday, one of the highest tolls since the October ceasefire aimed at stopping the fighting. A day after Israel accused Hamas of new ceasefire violations, strikes hit locations throughout Gaza, including lethal ones on an apartment building in Gaza City and a tent camp in Khan Younis, officials at hospitals that received the bodies said.

items.title: Israeli strikes kill at least 30 across Gaza in one of highest tolls since October ceasefire
items.standfirst: New Israeli air strikes slammed targets across Gaza on Saturday, including a Gaza City residential building and a tent camp Khan Younis, killing at least 30 people, hospital officials said. The strikes come just a day before the announced reopening of the enclave's Rafah crossing with Egypt and mark a continually rising death toll as Israel and Hamas trade accusations of violating the ceasefire.
items.content: New Israeli air strikes slammed targets across Gaza on Saturday, including a Gaza City residential building and a tent camp Khan Younis, killing at least 30 people, hospital officials said. The strikes come just a day before the announced reopening of the enclave's Rafah crossing with Egypt and mark a continually rising death toll as Israel and Hamas trade accusations of violating the ceasefire.

items.title: Israeli strikes kill at least 30 Palestinians in Gaza, hospital officials say

items.content: At least 30 Palestinians have been killed in Israeli strikes on Saturday, according to hospitals in Gaza.

clusters.title: 'We don't want them here': Italians in Milan protest ICE's role in Winter Olympics
clusters.neutral_headline: Milan protests decry ‘creeping fascism’ of ICE role at Winter Olympics

items.title: 'We don't want them here': Italians in Milan protest ICE's role in Winter Olympics
items.standfirst: The Department of Homeland Security said that Homeland Security Investigations, a unit of ICE, will be in Italy for the 2026 Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics to support U.S. diplomatic security. NBC News' Claudio Lavanga spoke to Italians who gathered in Milan to protest ICE's role at the Games.
items.content: The Department of Homeland Security said that Homeland Security Investigations, a unit of ICE, will be in Italy for the 2026 Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics to support U.S. diplomatic security. NBC News' Claudio Lavanga spoke to Italians who gathered in Milan to protest ICE's role at the Games.

items.title: Milan protesters call for U.S. ICE agents to leave Italy as Winter Games approach
items.standfirst: An ICE unit from the US Department of Homeland Security is playing a role providing security at the Winter Games. At past Olympics, their involvement would have been unremarkable. But after the violence in Minneapolis, many Italians protesting in Milan say ICE agents are no longer welcome.
items.content: An ICE unit from the US Department of Homeland Security is playing a role providing security at the Winter Games. At past Olympics, their involvement would have been unremarkable. But after the violence in Minneapolis, many Italians protesting in Milan say ICE agents are no longer welcome.(Image credit: PIERO CRUCIATTI)

items.title: Milan protests decry ‘creeping fascism’ of ICE role at Winter Olympics
items.standfirst: Demonstrators in Milan protest United State's ICE unit role at Milano-Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics.
items.content: Demonstrators in Milan protest United State's ICE unit role at Milano-Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics.

items.title: 'Creeping fascism': Milan protesters slam ICE deployment at Winter Olympics
items.standfirst: Protesters on Saturday gathered at Milan's Piazza XXV Aprile, a square named for the date of Italy’s liberation from Nazi fascism in 1945, to protest the deployment of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents during the upcoming Winter Olympics there. Demonstrators in the Italian city denounced what they called "creeping fascism" in the US.
items.content: Protesters on Saturday gathered at Milan's Piazza XXV Aprile, a square named for the date of Italy’s liberation from Nazi fascism in 1945, to protest the deployment of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents during the upcoming Winter Olympics there. Demonstrators in the Italian city denounced what they called "creeping fascism" in the US.

items.title: Hundreds protest against ICE role in Winter Olympics in Milan
items.standfirst: Hundreds of protesters have gathered in Milan, Italy, to protest against the deployment of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) staff at the upcoming Winter Olympics.
items.content: Hundreds of protesters have gathered in Milan, Italy, to protest against the deployment of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) staff at the upcoming Winter Olympics.

items.title: Explosion in Iranian port city ahead of Iran's naval drill in the Strait of Hormuz
items.standfirst: The blast happened a day before a planned naval drill by Iran in the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf through which a fifth of all oil traded passes.
items.content: The blast happened a day before a planned naval drill by Iran in the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf through which a fifth of all oil traded passes.

items.title: Five killed in gas explosions in Iran, officials say
items.standfirst: Fourteen people are reportedly injured after separate blasts were reported on Saturday.
items.content: Fourteen people are reportedly injured after separate blasts were reported on Saturday.

items.title: Deadly blast rips Iranian port city as Tehran plans naval drills in Strait of Hormuz
items.standfirst: An explosion at a building in the southern Iranian port city of Bandar Abbas on Saturday killed one person and wounded 14, according to authorities. The blast came a day before a planned Iranian naval drill in the strategic Strait of Hormuz. Amid frantic regional diplomatic efforts to de-escalate tensions, President Donald Trump on Saturday said Iran was "taking to us".
items.content: An explosion at a building in the southern Iranian port city of Bandar Abbas on Saturday killed one person and wounded 14, according to authorities. The blast came a day before a planned Iranian naval drill in the strategic Strait of Hormuz. Amid frantic regional diplomatic efforts to de-escalate tensions, President Donald Trump on Saturday said Iran was "taking to us".

items.title: Deadly blast in Iran’s Bandar Abbas caused by gas leak, official says
items.standfirst: Local fire official says gas leak likely caused explosion that ripped through residential building in Iranian port city.
items.content: Local fire official says gas leak likely caused explosion that ripped through residential building in Iranian port city.

items.title: Gas leaks blamed for explosions in two Iranian cities
items.standfirst: An explosion reported on Saturday at a residential building in the southern Iranian city of Bandar Abbas on the Gulf coast was the result of a gas leak, according to the local fire chief. Another explosions in the city of Ahvaz near the Iraqi border had also earlier been blamed on a gas leak, according to state media.
items.content: An explosion reported on Saturday at a residential building in the southern Iranian city of Bandar Abbas on the Gulf coast was the result of a gas leak, according to the local fire chief. Another explosions in the city of Ahvaz near the Iraqi border had also earlier been blamed on a gas leak, according to state media.

items.title: Explosions at two Iranian cities amid rising tensions with US
items.standfirst: At least one person was killed and 14 injured in an explosion in the ⁠southern Iranian port of Bandar Abbas on Saturday, a local official told Iranian news agencies, but the cause of the blast was not known. Separately, four people were killed after a gas explosion in the city of Ahvaz near the Iraqi border, according to state-run Tehran Times. The blasts come at a tense time after a major US military deployment to the region.
items.content: At least one person was killed and 14 injured in an explosion in the ⁠southern Iranian port of Bandar Abbas on Saturday, a local official told Iranian news agencies, but the cause of the blast was not known. Separately, four people were killed after a gas explosion in the city of Ahvaz near the Iraqi border, according to state-run Tehran Times. The blasts come at a tense time after a major US military deployment to the region.

items.title: Iran explosions: What we know so far
items.standfirst: An explosion rocked the southern Iranian port of Bandar Abbas on Saturday, Iranian news agencies said, but the cause of the blast was not known. The semi-official Tasnim news agency said that social media reports alleging that a Revolutionary Guard navy commander had been targeted were "completely false". Separately, four people were killed after a gas explosion in the city of Ahvaz near the Iraqi border, according to state-run Tehran Times. France 24’s international affairs editor Kethevane Gorjestani takes a look at what we know so far.
items.content: An explosion rocked the southern Iranian port of Bandar Abbas on Saturday, Iranian news agencies said, but the cause of the blast was not known. The semi-official Tasnim news agency said that social media reports alleging that a Revolutionary Guard navy commander had been targeted were "completely false". Separately, four people were killed after a gas explosion in the city of Ahvaz near the Iraqi border, according to state-run Tehran Times. France 24’s international affairs editor Kethevane Gorjestani takes a look at what we know so far.

items.title: Partial government shutdown begins as funding lapses despite Senate deal

items.title: Trump has tapped a new Federal Reserve chair. Has he finally found his yes-man?
items.standfirst: Trump nominated Kevin Warsh, an ex-Fed governor, for the role as the White House continues to attack Jerome PowellThe US Federal Reserve requires “strong, sound and steady leadership”, according to Donald Trump. The president found a man to lead the central bank who would “provide exactly that type of leadership”, he declared.“He’s strong, he’s committed and he’s smart.”This is not how Trump described Kevin Warsh, the former Fed governor whom he unveiled as his new nominee to chair the central bank on Friday – but how he hailed Jerome Powell, the current Fed chair, when nominating him for the job about eight years ago. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Mine collapses in eastern Congo, leaving at least 200 dead
clusters.neutral_headline: More than 200 killed in mine collapse in DR Congo

items.title: Mine collapses in eastern Congo, leaving at least 200 dead
items.standfirst: The collapse happened Wednesday due to heavy rains at the rebel-controlled Rubaya mines. Congo is a major supplier of coltan, which contains a key component in the production of smartphones.
items.content: The collapse happened Wednesday due to heavy rains at the rebel-controlled Rubaya mines. Congo is a major supplier of coltan, which contains a key component in the production of smartphones.(Image credit: Moses Sawasawa)

items.title: More than 200 killed in mine collapse in DR Congo
items.standfirst: The mine gave way after heavy rains on Wednesday, a local rebel spokesman says.
items.content: The mine gave way after heavy rains on Wednesday, a local rebel spokesman says.

clusters.title: Actor Demond Wilson, star of "Sanford and Son," dies at 79
clusters.neutral_headline: Actor Demond Wilson, star of "Sanford and Son," dies at 79

items.title: Actor Demond Wilson, star of "Sanford and Son," dies at 79
items.standfirst: Actor Demond Wilson died in his California home due to complications from prostate cancer, CBS News learned on Saturday. He starred alongside Redd Foxx in "Sanford and Son," one of the biggest TV hits of the 1970s.
items.content: Actor Demond Wilson died in his California home due to complications from prostate cancer, CBS News learned on Saturday. He starred alongside Redd Foxx in "Sanford and Son," one of the biggest TV hits of the 1970s.

items.title: 'Sanford and Son' co-star Demond Wilson dies at 79
items.standfirst: The actor was best known for playing Lamont Sanford, opposite Redd Foxx's Fred Sanford in the hit 1970s sitcom. Wilson died Friday from complications related to cancer, his publicist said.
items.content: Sanford and Son. The actor played Lamont Sanford, the disgruntled offspring of Redd Foxx's Fred Sanders (left), in the hit 1970s NBC sitcom.'/>The actor was best known for playing Lamont Sanford, opposite Redd Foxx's Fred Sanford in the hit 1970s sitcom. Wilson died Friday from complications related to cancer, his publicist said.(Image credit: NBC Television)

items.title: Waymo reportedly raising a $16B funding round
items.standfirst: Waymo has nearly finalized a new $16 billion funding round that will value the robotaxi company at $110 billion, according to the Financial Times. More than three-fourths of that funding will reportedly come from a source close to home — Alphabet, where Waymo is a subsidiary. (The company was…

items.title: Waymo Seeking About $16 Billion Near $110 Billion Valuation
items.standfirst: Waymo, Alphabet Inc.’s autonomous driving unit, is aiming to raise about $16 billion in a financing round that would value the unit at nearly $110 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.
items.content: Waymo, Alphabet Inc.’s autonomous driving unit, is aiming to raise about $16 billion in a financing round that would value the unit at nearly $110 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

clusters.title: Pakistan military says it has killed 92 militants in Balochistan
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistan military says it has killed 92 militants in Balochistan

items.title: Pakistan military says it has killed 92 militants in Balochistan
items.standfirst: It says 15 security personnel and 18 civilians were also killed after militants attacked many cities in Pakistan's province.
items.content: It says 15 security personnel and 18 civilians were also killed after militants attacked many cities in Pakistan's province.

items.title: Who are the Baloch Liberation Army, the group behind Pakistan attacks?
items.standfirst: Some 10 police and security personnel and 11 civilians were killed during orchestrated militant attacks across the southwestern province of Balochistan Saturday, Pakistan officials said. The banned separatist group Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) claimed responsibility for the attacks in a region that has faced a decades-long insurgency by ethnic Baloch militant groups. France 24’s correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah takes a closer look.
items.content: Some 10 police and security personnel and 11 civilians were killed during orchestrated militant attacks across the southwestern province of Balochistan Saturday, Pakistan officials said. The banned separatist group Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) claimed responsibility for the attacks in a region that has faced a decades-long insurgency by ethnic Baloch militant groups. France 24’s correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah takes a closer look.

items.title: Separatists launch 'coordinated' attacks in southwest Pakistan
items.standfirst: Ethnic Baloch separatists launched "coordinated" attacks across Pakistan's Balochistan province on Saturday, killing at least ten policemen, officials said, the latest violence in insurgency-hit southwest region. FRANCE 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah reports that the situation in the provincial capital of Quetta remains tense.
items.content: Ethnic Baloch separatists launched "coordinated" attacks across Pakistan's Balochistan province on Saturday, killing at least ten policemen, officials said, the latest violence in insurgency-hit southwest region. FRANCE 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah reports that the situation in the provincial capital of Quetta remains tense.

items.title: Scores killed in Baloch separatist attack in southwest Pakistan
items.standfirst: Baloch separatists launched a deadly series of "coordinated' attacks at more than 12 locations in Pakistan's Balochistan province on Saturday, an official said. At least 11 civilians, 10 security officials and 67 insurgents were killed, according to authorities.
items.content: Baloch separatists launched a deadly series of "coordinated' attacks at more than 12 locations in Pakistan's Balochistan province on Saturday, an official said. At least 11 civilians, 10 security officials and 67 insurgents were killed, according to authorities.

items.standfirst: Nvidia Corp. supports “every developer” that uses its software, Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang said, after a US lawmaker accused the chip giant of offering technical support that helped China’s DeepSeek improve its artificial intelligence model. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Nvidia Corp. supports “every developer” that uses its software, Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang said, after a US lawmaker accused the chip giant of offering technical support that helped China’s DeepSeek improve its artificial intelligence model. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Chicago mayor orders police to investigate alleged illegal ICE activity in city
clusters.neutral_headline: Chicago mayor orders police to investigate alleged illegal ICE activity in city

items.title: Chicago mayor orders police to investigate alleged illegal ICE activity in city
items.standfirst: Brandon Johnson gives police ‘clear procedure’ to follow if they witness or get reports of agents involved in illegal activityChicago’s mayor Brandon Johnson has ordered Chicago police to investigate and document alleged illegal activity by federal immigration (ICE) agents in the city, a move that will escalate tensions over jurisdiction between local and federal authorities.The executive order, titled ICE on Notice, gives Chicago police “clear procedure” to follow if they witness or receive reports of ICE agents involved in illegal activity and refer evidence of potential violations to city prosecutors. Continue reading...
items.content: Brandon Johnson gives police ‘clear procedure’ to follow if they witness or get reports of agents involved in illegal activityChicago’s mayor Brandon Johnson has ordered Chicago police to investigate and document alleged illegal activity by federal immigration (ICE) agents in the city, a move that will escalate tensions over jurisdiction between local and federal authorities.The executive order, titled ICE on Notice, gives Chicago police “clear procedure” to follow if they witness or receive reports of ICE agents involved in illegal activity and refer evidence of potential violations to city prosecutors. Continue reading...

Johnson’s decree — dubbed the “ICE on Notice” order —…

items.title: Keir Starmer calls on Andrew to testify in US over Jeffrey Epstein links
items.standfirst: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, who was stripped of his royal titles last year, features heavily in the latest tranche of the Epstein filesKeir Starmer has said Andrew Mounbatten-Windsor should testify before the US Congress about his links to the late child sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.The prime minister, who is in Japan for a meeting with its premier, Sanae Takaichi, was asked by journalists if the former prince should apologise to the disgraced financier’s victims and give evidence about what he knew about his crimes. Continue reading...

clusters.title: US envoy Witkoff holds ‘constructive’ Ukraine talks with Russia
clusters.neutral_headline: US envoy Witkoff says Ukraine talks with Russia ‘productive’

items.title: US envoy Witkoff holds ‘constructive’ Ukraine talks with Russia
items.standfirst: US envoy Steve Witkoff on Saturday said he had "productive and constructive meetings" with Kirill Dmitriev, Russian President Vladimir Putin's top economic adviser and special envoy, in Florida. The talks came a day before a scheduled meeting in Abu Dhabi between Ukrainian and Russian negotiators amid the Trump administration's drive to end the Ukraine war.
items.content: US envoy Steve Witkoff on Saturday said he had "productive and constructive meetings" with Kirill Dmitriev, Russian President Vladimir Putin's top economic adviser and special envoy, in Florida. The talks came a day before a scheduled meeting in Abu Dhabi between Ukrainian and Russian negotiators amid the Trump administration's drive to end the Ukraine war.

items.title: US envoy Witkoff says Ukraine talks with Russia ‘productive’
items.standfirst: The talks come just a day before a second round of US-mediated talks between Russia and Ukraine in Abu Dhabi.
items.content: The talks come just a day before a second round of US-mediated talks between Russia and Ukraine in Abu Dhabi.

clusters.title: Democrats accuse DoJ of not releasing millions of Epstein files despite legal requirement
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump, Musk cited in new batch of Epstein files released by US DoJ

items.title: Democrats accuse DoJ of not releasing millions of Epstein files despite legal requirement
items.standfirst: Justice department on Friday released 3m pages and lawmakers accuse it of not releasing roughly 50% of recordsSurvivors, lawmakers and watchdog groups accused Donald Trump’s justice department of withholding records it is legally required to release following the disclosure of millions of files from the investigation into the disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.The justice department on Friday released 3m pages of documents from its investigation into the millionaire financier’s sexual abuse of young girls and his interactions with wealthy and powerful figures, including Trump and former president Bill Clinton. The release was an effort to comply with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, and, according to US deputy attorney general, Todd Blanche, includes more than 2,000 videos and 180,000 images, all subject to “extensive redactions”. Continue reading...
items.content: Justice department on Friday released 3m pages and lawmakers accuse it of not releasing roughly 50% of recordsSurvivors, lawmakers and watchdog groups accused Donald Trump’s justice department of withholding records it is legally required to release following the disclosure of millions of files from the investigation into the disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.The justice department on Friday released 3m pages of documents from its investigation into the millionaire financier’s sexual abuse of young girls and his interactions with wealthy and powerful figures, including Trump and former president Bill Clinton. The release was an effort to comply with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, and, according to US deputy attorney general, Todd Blanche, includes more than 2,000 videos and 180,000 images, all subject to “extensive redactions”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump, Musk cited in new batch of Epstein files released by US DoJ
items.standfirst: The US Justice Department has released more than 3 million pages of records from its investigative files on Jeffrey Epstein, resuming disclosures about what the government knew about the millionaire financier’s sexual abuse of young girls. The latest release includes thousands of references to US President Donald Trump, hundreds to Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, formerly known as Britain’s Prince Andrew, and details of conversations with billionaire Tesla founder Elon Musk.
items.content: The US Justice Department has released more than 3 million pages of records from its investigative files on Jeffrey Epstein, resuming disclosures about what the government knew about the millionaire financier’s sexual abuse of young girls. The latest release includes thousands of references to US President Donald Trump, hundreds to Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, formerly known as Britain’s Prince Andrew, and details of conversations with billionaire Tesla founder Elon Musk.

items.title: Ukraine sees quieter night as Trump says Putin will not attack its cities

items.content: Russia said the US president requested a pause in strikes on Kyiv until 1 February, a move Trump said was prompted by the cold weather.
